Those in favor of the death penalty argue that it provides a stronger deterrent effect than life in prison because it is the ultimate punishment. The thinking is that if criminals know they could face execution, they will be less likely to commit serious crimes out of fear of this consequence. Some studies have found that each execution may deter a number of homicides, suggesting the death penalty does have a deterrent effect.

However, those opposed to the death penalty argue that life imprisonment is an equally strong or even stronger deterrent. They point out that life in prison means the offender will never be free again and must spend their entire life paying for their crime. The certainty of this punishment may be more of a deterrent than the possibility (but low probability) of being executed. Many criminologists believe the certainty and swiftness of punishment are more important for deterrence than the severity.

Additionally, there is the issue of the lengthy appeals process in death penalty cases, which can delay execution for many years. This undermines the deterrent effect by inserting so much time between the crime and the ultimate punishment. With life imprisonment, the punishment begins immediately after conviction.

Ultimately, the evidence on whether the death penalty provides a unique deterrent effect is mixed and inconclusive. Some studies find a deterrent effect, while others do not. The National Academy of Sciences concluded in 2012 that research on this topic is not scientifically valid or precise enough to draw any conclusions about deterrence. 

So in summary, while there are arguments on both sides, the scientific consensus is that we cannot definitively say whether the death penalty deters crime more than life imprisonment. It remains an open question without a clear answer. Both punishments have potential deterrent value but also drawbacks. The death penalty raises additional concerns about the risk of executing the innocent, while life imprisonment has very high costs. There is still much uncertainty and debate around this issue.
